subject: GEOGRAPHY
text: Name the various amusements of the fair.

subject: GEOGRAPHY
text: What was the least popular amusement and why?

subject: GEOGRAPHY
text: What noises could be heard at the fair?

subject: GEOGRAPHY
text: Give the fortune-teller’s actual words to the writer.

subject: GEOGRAPHY
text: Compare the interior of the fortune-teller’s grot with that of the tent occupied by the two men.

subject: GEOGRAPHY
text: Describe briefly in your own words the roundabout, and the people on it; and write down the actual announcement.

subject: GEOGRAPHY
text: Rewrite the last sentence (“Once .... meadow.”) in correct English.

subject: GEOGRAPHY
text: Explain carefully the following phrases as used in the passage: a swirl of light, recapturing their youth, journeying to nowhere, traitors’ heads on the Tower, could languish unseen.

subject: GEOGRAPHY
text: Give the meaning of the following words as used in the passage: vibrating, pillion, disposition, benign, reminiscence.

subject: GEOGRAPHY
text: Select from the passage three words describing the sound of music, and distinguish shades of meaning in them.

subject: GEOGRAPHY
text: Combine the following statements into a single sentence, using a principal and three subordinate clauses, or a principal clause, a participial phrase and two subordinate clauses: He had not gone far—he suddenly felt very tired—he lay down under a tree—it afforded abundant shade.

subject: GEOGRAPHY
text: Give the plural of the following: tobacco, himself, son-in-law, omnibus, radius, child’s.

subject: GEOGRAPHY
text: Write down the present participle of the following verbs: occur, gallop, die, hinge, quarrel, frolic.

subject: GEOGRAPHY
text: Name six characters in the Bible noted respectively for strength, wisdom, patience, treachery, indecision, leadership.
